Material used.Description: Recombinant wild type and mutant α-Synuclein variants were expressed, purified, and used for fluorescence measurements.

Readout description.Result Description: The A53T substitution significantly increases the growth rate of fibril assembly, leading to faster aggregation kinetics compared to human wild-type α-Synuclein.
The S87N substitution, in combination with A53T, shortens the lag time of fibril assembly, indicating a synergistic effect on nucleation.

Biological replicates.Description: At least six replicates were performed on each variant to calculate averaged lag times and growth rates.

Basic positive control.Description: Human wild-type α-Synuclein (HHH) was used as a reference for comparison of growth rates and lag times.

Statistical analysis method.Statistical analysis method: Mean and standard deviation were calculated for lag times and growth rates; factorial analysis was used to assess synergistic effects of substitutions.

Threshold for normal readout.Threshold for normal readout: Growth rates and lag times similar to human wild-type α-Synuclein (HHH).

Threshold for abnormal readout.Threshold for abnormal readout: Growth rates significantly higher or lag times significantly shorter than human wild-type α-Synuclein (HHH).

Material used.Description: Fibrils grown during ThT kinetic experiments were used for TEM analysis.

Readout description.Result Description: Fibril morphology for variants with A53T substitution showed typical amyloid fibril structures with widths around 10 nm and varying lengths.
Fibril morphology for variants with S87N substitution showed typical amyloid fibril structures with widths around 10 nm and varying lengths.

Threshold for normal readout.Threshold for normal readout: Fibril morphology consistent with non-amyloid structures.

Threshold for abnormal readout.Threshold for abnormal readout: Fibril morphology consistent with amyloid structures (widths around 10 nm, lengths from 20 nm to 2 μm).

Material used.Description: 15N and 13C labeled α-Synuclein variants were used for NMR experiments to analyze secondary structure propensities.

Readout description.Result Description: Variants with A53T substitution showed more positive SSP scores around position 53, indicating a preference for helical conformations in the monomer ensemble.
Variants with S87N substitution did not show significant differences in SSP scores around position 87 compared to wild-type.

Technical replicates.Description: Duplicate triple resonance spectra were collected on different machines several months apart.

Threshold for normal readout.Threshold for normal readout: SSP scores indicating β-sheet conformations similar to human wild-type α-Synuclein.

Threshold for abnormal readout.Threshold for abnormal readout: SSP scores indicating a shift towards helical conformations around position 53.
